item.title: The Invisible Bakery
item.description:
Bushwick wears its own cologne,
a delicate infusion of fish guts
and the unsorted trash of local history
accumulating in gutters,

But then there’s the Butter Street,
the Invisible Bakery, the air celebrates
the swift movements of floured hands,
folding and rolling and folding again.

item.title: The New Bridge
item.description:
A machine torn straight from the pages
of the War of the Worlds,
it has dug claws into the soil of old Dundrum
and hunkered down on its haunches.

St. George’s Bells peel its arrival.
Spider on spider on spider,
little feet disturb hairs
on the back of my hands,
and ivy sinks first roots
into concrete - the webs we weave,

the bridges new lovers build for each other,
rigging stretches to the sky
and wind plays the cables like a harp.
It is like a beached ship, you whispered.
Before it landed here on our small planet,
a sail of purest whitest energy
stretched from that thin curved mast,
I replied.

Those pillars hide the shaft of a glass elevator
and, deep in the caverns they have hollowed
beneath the streets of Dundrum,
small fat-eyed men with silver suits and laser guns
watch us as we make love on the tracks
of Dundrum Luas bridge-
stars pulsing above us,
cars pulsing below
and Mars hovering, unblinking,
an ever-watchful eye.

item.title: The Autumn Guard
item.description:
The wind is in the saplings
and they are loosing leaves
for the first time.

“What are these red birds
skittering across the lawn?
Those birds were mine!”

in silence you were born
I buried you beneath a sap maple

that it may draw sweetness
from you

item.title: The Kiss
item.description:
I have followed the tracks of deer
through virgin land,
slept on dry moss
and catkins
beneath the boughs of a silver birch.

I have eaten fresh snow
from winter fields,
still whipped wattled with blades
of ryegrass
and flecked with white clover.

I have licked the wind
from the devil’s mountain.

I have tasted the yellowed lace
of an older woman’s collar,
caught her white neck
on my tongue,
an apparition.

I have marked foundations
and slung lines
for the borders of a new field,
only to fly home
leaving it unsown.

item.title: love like a hurricane
item.description:
love like a hurricane
breaks boughs

lightning tiger
dewdrop spider

love like summer rain
softens brittle grass

item.title: The Art of Love
item.description:
Love has left me wondering
where I left my shoes and my socks
and my bra
and my trousers
and my blouse –

caught on the dresser
riding the headboard
snagged on the doorknob
under the bed –

over the rooftops
away with the wind
riding the river
feeling it bend –

snagging on lilypads
playing with fish
nibbling at bedrock
making it itch –
love has left me wondering.

item.title: Otter's First Love
item.description:
Otter’s first love was not
a rough wave,
soft fingers, strong wrists –
not the shrill call
of gulls
moving against cliffs –
not the smooth sweep
of stone in paw,
the cracking of the oyster –

floating on his back,
he watched the boats
come in to land –
might he hoist a bright sail
over his belly too
and feel it tauten
in the wind?

item.title: lolla rossa, touches herself
item.description:
it often strikes me
this lettuce has many hands
all clasped and curling
a dead bee

what is she waiting for?

they always talk of lettuce
and the heart
how it is so fine and so tender

item.title: The House on the Hill
item.description:
My life on paper is rakish,
tight as a papoose –
rolling like beads across the page,
fractals from seed to weed - it runs wild.

I have known the moon and her shadows,
felt the love that has dried
on her soft white hands,
scabbing them over, pocking them.

I have built myself a house –
it is enormous and unfinished, it is the deer,
it is the oak tree, it is the sea –
I will sit in the kitchen

and make a pot of tea.
